Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(t) = {\\int_{0}^{t} e^{sA} x(s) ds} \\) where \\( A \\) is a constant matrix, and \\( x(t) \\) is a function defined by some physical or chemical process. We assess the effect of the linear operator \\( L(z) = Bz \\), with B being another constant matrix, on the system.

If the operator \\( L(z) \\) is applied to \\( z(t) \\) at t = 0 and the system is allowed to evolve without further intervention, will the outcome at any time t be equivalent to the evolution of \\( z(t) \\) without application of \\( L \\)?
Explanation: Applying the operator \\( L \\) modifies the initial expression to \\( Bz(0) \\), thus altering the solution trajectory. The multiplication by matrix B affects the integration outcome differently than if it were just \\( z(t) \\) evolving under its original definition.
